infodynamics.measures.continuous

Interface ActiveInfoStorageCalculator

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorGaussian, ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorKernel, ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorKraskov, ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorViaMutualInfo

    public interface ActiveInfoStorageCalculator
    Interface for implementations of Active Information Storage estimators on continuous univariate data (ie double[] arrays).

    See definition of Active Information Storage (AIS) by Lizier et al. below. Basically, AIS is the mutual information between the past state of a time-series process X and its next value. The past state at time n is represented by an embedding vector of k values from X_n backwards, each separated by \tau steps, giving X^k_n = [ X_{n-(k-1)\tau}, ... , X_{n-\tau}, X_n]. We call k the embedding dimension, and \tau the embedding delay. AIS is then the mutual information between X^k_n and X_{n+1}.

    Usage of the child classes implementing this interface is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator;
    2. Set properties using setProperty(String, String);
    3. Initialise the calculator using initialise() or initialise(int) or initialise(int, int);
    4. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using:
      • setObservations(double[]) or setObservations(double[], boolean[]) for calculations based on single time-series, OR
      • The following sequence:
        1. startAddObservations(), then
        2. One or more calls to addObservations(double[]) or addObservations(double[], int, int), then
        3. finaliseAddObservations();
    5. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average AIS: computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • the local AIS values for these samples: computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
      • local AIS values for a specific set of samples: computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[])
      • the distribution of AIS values under the null hypothesis of no relationship between past sequences in the series and the next value: computeSignificance(int) or computeSignificance(int[][]).
    6. Return to step 2 or 3 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.

    References:

    • J.T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A.Y. Zomaya, "Local measures of information storage in complex distributed computation", Information Sciences, vol. 208, pp. 39-54, 2012.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

    • Field Detail

      • K_PROP_NAME

        static final java.lang.String K_PROP_NAME
        Property name for embedding length k of the past history vector (1 by default).
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • TAU_PROP_NAME

        static final java.lang.String TAU_PROP_NAME
        Property name for embedding delay \tau of the past history vector (1 by default). The delay exists between points in the past k-vector but there is always only one time step between the past k-vector and the next observation.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • setProperty

        void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
               java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Set properties for the underlying calculator implementation. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Property names defined at the interface level, and what their values should represent, include:

        • K_PROP_NAME -- embedding length k of the past history vector
        • TAU_PROP_NAME -- embedding delay between each of the k points in the past history vector.

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Note that implementing classes may defined additional properties.

        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • getProperty

        java.lang.String getProperty(java.lang.String propertyName)
                             throws java.lang.Exception
        Get current property values for the calculator.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, are the same as those for setProperty(String, String)

        Unknown property values are responded to with a null return value.

        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        Returns:
        current value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

                     throws java.lang.Exception

        Parameters:

      • startAddObservations

        void startAddObservations()

      • addObservations

        void addObservations(double[] observations)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Add more time-series for the computation of the PDF. The array observations must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called.
        Parameters:

      • addObservations

        void addObservations(double[] observations,
                   int startTime,
                   int numTimeSteps)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Add more time-series for the computation of the PDF, using only a sub-series of observations. The array observations must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called.
        Parameters:
        observations - time-series array of (univariate) samples, where the array index is time.
        startTime - first time index to extract samples from
        numTimeSteps - number of time steps to extract starting from startTime
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setObservations

        void setObservations(double[] observations,
                   boolean[] valid)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets a single time-series from which to compute the PDF for the AIS, subject to the validity of each sample in that series. Cannot be called in conjunction with other methods for setting/adding observations.
        Parameters:
        observations - time-series array of (univariate) samples, where the array index is time.
        valid - a time series (with indices the same as observations) indicating whether the entry in observations at that index is valid; we only take vectors as samples to add to the observation set where all points in the time series (even between points in the embedded k-vector with embedding delays) are valid.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        double computeAverageLocalOfObservations()
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the AIS from the previously-supplied samples.
        Returns:
        the AIS estimate
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the local AIS values for each of the previously-supplied samples.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations.

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as setObservations(double[]), then the return value is a single time-series of local AIS values corresponding to these samples (with the first (k-1)*tau + 1 values set to 0 since AIS is undefined there).

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as addObservations(double[]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array (without any (k-1)*tau + 1 leading 0 values).

        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local AIS values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[] newObservations)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the local AIS values for each of the supplied samples in newObservations.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in newObservations (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        Parameters:
        newObservations - time-series for which to compute local AIS values
        Returns:
        time-series of local AIS values corresponding to newObservations (the first (k-1)*tau + 1 values are set to 0 since AIS is undefined there)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for an invalid input array, e.g. of length less than k+1

      • computeSignificance

        EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the AIS would look like, under a null hypothesis that the previous k values of our samples had no relation to the next value in the time-series.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for AIS as a mutual information. Basically, the marginal PDFs of the past k values, and that of the next value, are preserved, while their joint PDF is destroyed, and the distribution of AIS under these conditions is generated.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int[][])) creates random shufflings of the next values for the surrogate AIS calculations.

        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to bootstrap to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the distribution of AIS scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the AIS would look like, under a null hypothesis that the previous k values of our samples had no relation to the next value in the time-series.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for AIS as a mutual information. Basically, the marginal PDFs of the past k values, and that of the next value, are preserved, while their joint PDF is destroyed, and the distribution of AIS under these conditions is generated.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int)) allows the user to specify how to construct the surrogates, such that repeatable results may be obtained.

        Parameters:
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the next values to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length L being the value returned by getNumObservations(), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(L-1).
        Returns:
        the distribution of AIS scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to the number L observations that were previously supplied.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • setDebug

        void setDebug(boolean debug)
        Set or clear debug mode for extra debug printing to stdout
        Parameters:
        debug - new setting for debug mode (on/off)

      • getLastAverage

        double getLastAverage()
        Return the AIS last calculated in a call to computeAverageLocalOfObservations() or computeLocalOfPreviousObservations() after the previous initialise() call.
        Returns:
        the last computed AIS value

      • getNumObservations

        int getNumObservations()
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Get the number of samples to be used for the PDFs here which have been supplied by calls to setObservations(double[]), addObservations(double[]) etc.

        Note that the number of samples is not equal to the length of time-series supplied (since we need to accumulate the first (k-1)*tau + 1 values of each time-series before taking a sample for AIS).

        Returns:
        the number of samples to be used for the PDFs
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
